column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Something
#Text=I do miss are the " next-previous " functions of the NeXT browser .
#Text=Current browsers only permit you to follow a link and then to run back and forth over the path you took ( " back " and " forward " ) .
#Text=The NeXT browser had the additional function of following the next link of the previous page ( " next " ) .
#Text=That allowed me to make a page which was a list of pages to be looked at and then to walk that " path " with a click per page .
#Text=It was a simple way to establish a path and save it , totally independently from the target pages and the servers .
#Text=A kind of " digest " .
#Text=I know , it 's possible to do this with Javascript , but it is not easy and you ca n't pass such a page in a simple way to just anyone .
#Text=We also had vector graphics .
#Text=I 'm afraid that SVG has failed , at least I do not see any sites that use it extensively .
#Text=Style sheets were also incorporated , not very advanced , but the idea was there .
#Text=CSS did break through .
#Text=Today I use mainly Safari because it uses CSS best and above all for the typography .
#Text=Even Firefox can learn from Safari 's typography .
#Text=Why is it that so few programs handle text well ?
#Text=Why is typography so lousy on the screen ?
#Text=Tabbed browsing is a concession to those who ca n't cope with a multitude of separate windows .
#Text=Do n't really need it .
#Text=The first browsers always opened a linked page in a new window .
#Text=But Windows does not use windows : it prefers full-screen .
#Text=Mosaic was one of the first browsers that used a single window .
#Text=Why do it simple when it 's possible to complicate things ?
#Text=Wikinews : Search engines have made the mass of data now on the WWW easily searchable .
#Text=How initially did you foresee the data being indexed ?
#Text=Robert Cailliau : Not at all !
#Text=Or by hand .
#Text=We had the " Virtual Library " or VL , the idea of indexing and classifying pages about a subject by voluntary work of a specialist in that subject .
#Text=A kind of Wikipedia , but with only the links : the content was distributed outside the VL .
#Text=The VL had a certain success , but demanded a lot of work .
#Text=The appearance of search engines made the VL unimportant .
#Text=The web broke up into servers .
#Text=The original " atom " of the web was the page , now it is the server .
#Text=Servers link very rarely to other servers and then almost always warn you :
#Text=" You will now leave our site !
